title: Nationals' circle of trust has been just six pitchers deep. Can the group see things through in World Series?
text:
CLOSE What I'm Hearing: Bob Nightengale delivers some news that Nationals fans don't wan't to hear about one of their ace pitchers. USA TODAY

HOUSTON – Come Tuesday night at Minute Maid Park, the Washington Nationals will stare down elimination for the fourth time this postseason, trailing by a game in this World Series and tasked with toppling future Hall of Famer Justin Verlander to keep their season alive.

A 3-2 deficit is far from the only way the Nationals are trying to beat the odds, however. In fact, you could suggest they’ve been trying to do it all October with a historically challenging task:

Win a World Series with just six pitchers.

Make no mistake, the Nationals have certainly deployed more pitchers – 12 in all. Yet, as they’ve navigated a harrowing wild-card game, a five-game conquest of the Los Angeles Dodgers in the National League Division Series, a sweep of the St. Louis Cardinals in the NL Championship Series and this back-and-forth battle with the Houston Astros in the World Series, the Nationals’ blueprint has been clear.

When at all possible, they want the ball in the hands of starters Max Scherzer, Stephen Strasburg, Patrick Corbin and Anibal Sanchez – whether starting or in relief – as well as top bullpen arms Daniel Hudson and Sean Doolittle.

The plan worked brilliantly as the Nationals started the postseason on a staggering 10-2 run that gave them a 2-0 World Series lead over the Astros, with the series shifting to Washington for three games.

Stephen Strasburg is scheduled to start Game 6 for the Nationals. (Photo: Troy Taormina, USA TODAY Sports)

At that point, the Nationals’ Big Six had covered 88.6% of their total innings, more than any sextet in a decade, and included crucial relief outings from starters Strasburg, Scherzer and Corbin in the wild card and NLDS.

Not since the 2009 Yankees – who received 87.4% of their innings from CC Sabathia, Andy Pettitte, A.J. Burnett, Mariano Rivera, Joba Chamberlain and Phil Hughes – had a World Series club received so many innings from so few arms, according to the Elias Sports Bureau.

With Sabathia, Pettitte and Burnett pitching on three days’ rest – and benefiting from an AL Division Series sweep – the Yankees went 11-4 in winning their 27th World Series championship.

These Nationals are facing an even taller task – playing their way through a wild card game and then facing a 106-win Dodgers team in the NLDS and the 107-win Astros in the World Series.

It is a task the team’s top four starters began mentally preparing for as the club put its grip on a wild card berth.

“They’ve been unbelievable, they really have,” Nationals manager Dave Martinez said Monday before his club hopped a flight from Washington to Houston. “I’m proud of them, and this was all based on conversations I’ve had with them since September.

“They’re all in. They’re all in and I’m proud of every one of them.”

Now, they will have to finish the task without one of their stalwarts.

Scherzer was scratched before his Game 5 start on Sunday with spasms in his neck and right trapezius that rendered him unable to lift his arm. Scherzer received a cortisone shot Sunday and the club is hoping he can beat the odds and contribute in Game 7 should Strasburg carry them to a season-saving Game 6 win.

Yet the Astros managed to poke holes in the Nationals’ pitching foundation before Scherzer’s injury.

They hen-pecked Sanchez in Friday’s Game 3, scoring single runs in four innings as the righty recorded 16 outs. Houston won 4-1 to get back in the Series.

In Game 4, Corbin made his seventh appearance of the postseason – four relief outings tucked between three starts. Perhaps it’s just a coincidence, but Corbin’s starts have regressed:

Six innings, one earned run in the NLDS

Five innings, four earned runs in the NLCS.

And a 4-0 deficit after four innings of Saturday’s Game 5, though Corbin managed to complete six innings of an 8-1 loss.

Still, the Nationals probably aren’t here without Corbin’s crucial relief work in Game 5 of the NLDS, Game 2 of the NLCS and Game 1 of the World Series.

“That’s what it’s all about in the postseason. Everybody has to have the cleats on every single day,” says Hall of Famer and MLB Network analyst Pedro Martinez, who started and lost Game 6 of the 2009 World Series against the Yankees’ Pettitte. “You want to have the very best you can possibly have out there against the opposition.”

Indeed, it’s a mix-and-match strategy the Boston Red Sox used to perfection last year, when Chris Sale, David Price, Nathan Eovaldi and Rick Porcello toggled from starting to relieving as the Red Sox rolled through an 11-3 postseason to capture the 2018 World Series.

Still, even with Eovaldi chipping in an epic six-inning relief outing in an 18-inning World Series Game 3 loss, the Red Sox’s load management was remarkable. Their four starters plus relievers Joe Kelly and Craig Kimbrel accounted for 75% of the Red Sox’s 134 postseason innings.

Manager Alex Cora pushed the buttons brilliantly all October – and had a lot of buttons to push. Lefty Eduardo Rodriguez made one spot start and several key relief outings and right-handers Matt Barnes, Ryan Brasier and Heath Hembree were generally trusted with high-leverage situations in front of closer Kimbrel – or whichever Red Sox starter might be handling the eighth and ninth on a given night.

Martinez does not have that luxury. The Nationals’ regular-season bullpen ERA of 5.66 was the worst of any postseason qualifier, ever. A late-season makeover that most notably added Hudson improved the group significantly, but right-handers such as Fernando Rodney, rookie Tanner Rainey and Wander Suero fall more into the “if necessary” category rather than a preferred option.

Should they fall short, the Nationals may ultimately wonder how much difference one more reliable arm might have made.

Still, Martinez remains upbeat, lauding the group beyond the Big Six and noting that Rodney gamely took the ball every night in Games 3, 4 and 5.

The Nationals’ 0-3 performance in those games not coincidentally came as their Big Six inning percentage dropped to 81.2%. It should tick back up with Strasburg starting Game 6 and Hudson and Doolittle again rested.

Martinez does not expect a lack of volunteers to go above and beyond to win these final games – and a World Series championship.

“Sanchie told me he can throw 150 pitches,” Martinez said of Sanchez, the lone starter yet to appear out of the bullpen this postseason.

That might be a bit extreme, but the Nationals certainly expect their group to summon their reserves one more time – no matter how they may feel.

As for their bodies?

“You worry about that,” says Martinez, “after the season is over.”
description: The Nationals have navigated through the playoffs using mostly just six pitchers, covering nearly 82% of their total pitches.
